ON GEOMETRY OF THE RING OF ALGEBRAIC INTEGERS
IGOR NIKOLAEV1
Abstract. We study geometry of the ring of algebraic integers OK of a num-
ber eld K. Namely, it is proved that the inclusion Z  OK denes a covering
of the Riemann sphere CP 1 ramied over three points {0, 1, }. Our ap-
proach is based on the notion of a Serre C -algebra. As an application, a new
short proof of the Belyi Theorem is given.
1. Introduction
An interplay between arithmetic and geometry is an established and active area,
see e.g. [Weil 1949] [11]. The proof of Weils Conjectures was a motivation for the
notion of a scheme [Grothendieck 1960] [3]. Recall that Spec R of a commutative
ring R is the set of all prime ideals of R endowed with the Zariski topology. The
topology of Spec R is not Hausdor, yet it admits a cohomology theory and an
analog of the Lefschetz Fixed-Point Theorem [Grothendieck 1960] [3]. It appears
to be enough to prove Weils Conjectures.
Let Z be the ring of integers.
It was observed, that Spec Z looks like the
Riemann sphere CP 1 [Eisenbud  Harris 1999] [2, p. 83]. Such an analogy extends
to the inclusions Z  OK , where OK is the ring of integers of a number eld K. In
this case, one gets a ramied covering R  CP 1, where R is a Riemann surface.
The theory of schemes alone cannot explain this analogy, see e.g. [Manin 2006] [6,
Section 2.2].
The aim of our note is a proof of the relation between Z and CP 1. It shown
that the inclusion Z  OK denes a covering R  CP 1 ramied over three points
{0, 1, } (theorem 1.3). Our approach is based on the notion of a Serre C -algebra
[7, Section 5.3.1]. To formalize our results, we shall need the following denitions.

Our main result can be formulated as follows.
Theorem 1.3. Let Z be the ring of rational integers and let OK be the ring of
algebraic integers of a number eld K. Then:
(i) the Riemann sphere CP 1 is a karma of the ring Z;
(ii) there exists a Riemann surface R = R(K), such that R is a karma of the
ring OK;
(iii) the inclusion Z  OK denes a covering R  CP 1 ramied over three
points {0, 1, }.
The article is organized as follows. In Section 2 we briey review noncommutative
algebraic geometry and arithmetic groups. Theorem 1.3 is proved in Section 3. As
an application of theorem 1.3, we give a new short proof of the Belyi Theorem
[Belyi 1979] [1, Theorem 4].

4. Belyis Theorem
Such a theorem says that the algebraic curve R can be dened over a number
eld K if and only if there exist a covering R  CP 1 ramied over three points
of the Riemann sphere CP 1. This remarkable result was proved by [Belyi 1979] [1,
Theorem 4]. In this section we show that Belyis Theorem follows from theorem
1.3 and remark 3.1.
Theorem 4.1. (Belyis Theorem) A complete non-singular algebraic curve over
the eld of characteristic zero can be dened over an algebraic number eld if and
only if such a curve is a covering of the Riemann sphere CP 1 ramied over three
points.
